headline: FAA, Boeing Have Tussled Over Pilot Training for 737 MAX Software Fix
summary: Boeing Co. and U.S. air-safety regulators have been at odds over how much pilot training will be required in conjunction with a software fix for a flight-control feature at the center of the global grounding of the company’s 737 MAX jets, according to people familiar with the details.

headline: Corrections & Amplifications

headline: Terrorist Suspect Traced His Radicalization to a Visit to France
summary: The man charged with murder in the terrorist attacks in New Zealand wrote that what fueled him was a visit to Western Europe, in particular France. Many of the ideas in his screed—including its title—echo the writings of 72-year-old French author Renaud Camus.

headline: Yale Was Subpoenaed in November Related to Admissions-Cheating Scandal
summary: Rudy Meredith, the women’s soccer coach who was charged this week in relation to a sprawling college-admissions cheating scheme, resigned from Yale a day before the university received a federal grand-jury subpoena.

summary: Pacific Investment Management Co. said employees had used the services of the firm founded by the man at the center of a sweeping college-admissions scandal but it had “no information” suggesting they acted improperly.

headline: China Shields a Jihadist
summary: Beijing blocks a U.N. attempt to sanction the Kashmir killer.

headline: Pritzker’s Illinois Exit Ramp

headline: Digital Media Companies Tell Ad Giant It’s ‘All Hands on Deck’ to Pull New Zealand Video
summary: Facebook, Google and Twitter sought to reassure one of the world’s largest ad buyers they were striving to block violent content after video of the New Zealand terrorist attacks ricocheted around social media.

headline: U.S. Soccer President Surprised by Gender-Discrimination Suit Filed by Women’s Team

headline: It’s Hard to Spot the Terrorists Among the Trolls

headline: ‘Horizon’ Review: A Life on Earth

headline: $10 Billion Corporate Debt Sale Highlights Credit Market’s Recovery
summary: The world’s largest maker of car batteries is set to sell more than $10 billion worth of speculative-grade debt to fund its purchase by an investor-group led by Brookfield Business Partners, underscoring a resurgence in demand for low-rated bonds and loans.

headline: Boeing Chief Dennis Muilenburg Takes Low Profile After Crash

summary: The Pentagon failed to deliver on a promise by acting Defense Secretary Pat Shanahan to provide senators with a list of military construction projects that stand to be affected by President Trump’s emergency declaration, angering lawmakers.

summary: A Canadian businessman and philanthropist charged as one of the parents who participated in the nationwide college-admissions scheme pleaded not guilty Friday in federal court.

headline: Pilot Error Suspected in Fatal Atlas Air Cargo Crash

headline: Steinhoff Says Probe Found Accounting Irregularities

headline: Weak Economic Data Spurs U.S. Government Bond Rally

summary: Thomas Jefferson never contemplated that the exercise of religion would be walled off from the public square.

headline: Shireman and Allies Want To Kill For-Profit Schools

headline: ECB Official Calls for Fresh Look at Strategy, Tools

summary: As Brazil reels from one of its worst school shootings, the response from President Jair Bolsonaro’s administration and his supporters this week has echoed one heard in the U.S.: What Brazil needs, they say, is more guns.

summary: Today’s Top Supply Chain and Logistics News From WSJ.

summary: A passionate appreciator of small-batch, craftily laid-out tile takes a crack at cloaking her modest bathroom in ceramics worthy of a mansion.

summary: Somehow a vast realm of scattered islands was settled by a people with single language and distinctive customs—but no maps or compasses.

summary: Mel Brooks was ‘a gifted monster—explosive, whip-smart, vulgar, histrionic, egomaniacal, yet miraculously able to make people laugh their guts out.’

headline: Resilience: How Women Use Obstacles to Fuel Their Success
